title: Data set level reading and writing of encapsulated pixel data
body:
This PR extends the data set reader/writer so that it understands the logic of pixel sequences in the data set. This ultimately makes it possible to read files with an encapsulated pixel data. Resolves #23.

- Two new types of `DataToken`s: `PixelSequenceStart` (for the beginning of an encapsulated pixel data element) and `ItemValue` (for the raw contents of a pixel data item).
- Handle Pixel Data (7EF0, 0010) elements with an undefined length as encapsulated pixel data.
- New DICOM value variant PixelSequence allows you to represent DICOM pixel sequences in memory, including .
   - The current implementation of `InMemDicomObject` will collect all fragments and the offset table as-is into memory, thus retaining the fact that the pixel data is encapsulated.

The known caveat is that DICOM values and data tokens need to own the memory that they are working with. This means that data may still need to be copied around in some cases (e.g. saving a DICOM object to disk), and that each data token has to be fully contained in memory. This is likely to be reiterated to address the concerns presented in #1, so that tokens may instead borrow or refer to an arbitrary reader source.

title: Remove use of deprecated `Error::description`
body:
`Error::description` is fully deprecated now.

See: rust-lang/rust#66919

Also a couple of minor tidy ups.

title: Improve README docs
body:
- Add badges for documentation in docs.rs and entry in crates.io.
- Add crates.io and docs.rs badges to sub-crate READMEs.
- Add some links to extra information.

title: DICOM object writing
body:
This is another bulky set of contributions that ultimately enable users of DICOM-rs to write objects to a file. Resolves #15 as the MVP to writing, future issues related with the writing process can be made into more specific issues.

This was accompanied by several major changes, but I will summarize them here:

- substantially changed the parser and printer abstractions to be become _stateful_ decoder and encoder abstractions, thus being easier to understand their purpose and behaviour: they are like plain encoders/decoders, but target a specific byte source/sink and are aware of changes to text encoding.
- extended the dataset module with the `IntoTokens` trait and multiple useful implementations of it (including for the in-memory DICOM object type and for the file meta table).
- new experimental `dicom_value!` macro for constructing primitive values of variable cardinality.
- the method `RootDicomObject.write_to_file(path)` lets you write a complete DICOM object to disk.

title: Issue #33
body:
Hi Enet4,
I'm learning Rust and I sometimes bump into DICOM, so I gave issue #33 a try.
Keep up the good work, adeusinho.

title: Data set writing
body:
This PR adds substantial changes to the encoding and parser crates, which then allowed me to implement DICOM data set writing.

- Changed the Encode and Decode APIs to follow triple handshaking: `Encode` and `Decode` are monomorphized over writers and readers, whereas `EncodeTo<W>` and `DecodeFrom<S>` are restrained to a specific type. This allows implementations to be generic over the source/target while enabling object safe consumption.
- Changed some methods in encoder traits to expose the concrete number of bytes that were written
- Remove erased decoder: it was not useful
- Reorganized the data set reading and writing into its own module in the parser crate: `dataset`
- Add a `Printer` type; for the lack of a better name, this one is the dual to the `DicomParser` type, and is a stateful encoder which admits proper text encoding.
- Add a data set writer type in the parser crate
- Multiple bugs in the encoders were found and fixed.
- Move the primitive value parsing module to `encoding`
- Also re-export `chrono` via `dicom_core`

title: Add some robustness in meta file group reading
body:
Resolves #28.

- allow file meta group attributes in arbitrary order
- allow missing File Meta Information Version (the default is `(00H, 01H)`)

CC @ibaryshnikov

title: [parse] Prevent parsing of empty values
body:
If textual date/number values only contain whitespace, they should not be parsed at all. For some reason, the current `read_value` method was attempting to read something even with nothing to read.

This should solve some errors presented in #9 and #11, but it does not address the situation where the value is not in a DICOM-compliant format.

title: Parse explicit length sequences and items correctly
body:
This resolves #20. The parser should now know when the end of an item or a sequence is found, with delimiters (unknown length), or without delimiters (explicit length).

CC @ibaryshnikov @victorgabr

title: RootDicomObject into_inner + into_iter
body: Provides `RootDicomObject.into_inner` and makes it implement `IntoIterator`, currently by traversing the elements of the inner object (the meta table is not included).

title: Add DataElement.into_value
body: @ibaryshnikov I suppose this is what you had in mind? I am not opposed to the existence of this method, and at this stage, identifying useful methods and other pieces that feel missing from the API is much more important than rock-solid stability.

title: Transfer Syntax index abstraction & inventory-less registry
body:
This PR introduces a trait for transfer syntax dictionaries and makes it so that the main TS registry can work even without support for the `inventory` based registry. The inventory will be behind the Cargo feature `inventory-registry`, enabled by default only at the parent crate `dicom` and in end user tools such as `dcmdump`. If this is disabled, built-in TSes will still be available, but the registry will be unable to be extended. <s>We can think of ways to overcome this issue in future contributions.</s> This can be overcome by creating a new registry implementation.

This should address the main concern presented in #6, although I would be grateful to have this tested in that environment (CC @ibaryshnikov).

title: Update Travis CI to run Clippy
Running clippy.
body: Should we add these checks to the build server?

title: Sequence values with preceding spaces
body:
I was getting parsing errors without trimming any preceding spaces.

From [the standard](http://dicom.nema.org/dicom/2013/output/chtml/part05/sect_6.2.html):

> A string of characters representing either a fixed point number or a floating point number. A fixed point number shall contain only the characters 0-9 with an optional leading "+" or "-" and an optional "." to mark the decimal point. A floating point number shall be conveyed as defined in ANSI X3.9, with an "E" or "e" to indicate the start of the exponent. Decimal Strings **may be padded with leading or trailing spaces.** Embedded spaces are not allowed.

title: implemented Debug for Tag to print in hex
body:
Motivation: provide useful output for searching tag in dictionary.
Before `println!("{:?}", tag)` would print `Tag(32736, 16)`, after: `Tag(0x7FE0, 0x0010)`, and now it's easy to find `E { tag: Tag(0x7FE0, 0x0010), alias: "PixelData"`
